articles.headline: Saudis’ Role in Iraq Frustrates U.S. Officials
articles.snippet: Bush administration officials are expressing increasing anger at what they say has been Saudi Arabia’s counterproductive role in the Iraq war.
articles.abstract: Bush administration officials are expressing increasing anger at what they say has been Saudi Arabia’s counterproductive role in the Iraq war.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Helene Cooper, Mark Mazzetti and Jim Rutenberg, and written by Ms. Cooper.

articles.headline: Easy Credit Evaporates, and So Does the Market’s Buyout Frenzy
articles.snippet: The rationing of credit led investors Thursday to erase the takeover premiums that had propped up share prices for dozens of companies that had been considered buyout targets.
articles.abstract: The rationing of credit led investors Thursday to erase the takeover premiums that had propped up share prices for dozens of companies that had been considered buyout targets.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Swabs in Hand, Hospital Cuts Deadly Infections
articles.snippet: A veterans’ hospital in Pittsburgh has significantly reduced the number of patients who develop deadly drug-resistant infections, long a problem in the U.S.
articles.abstract: A veterans’ hospital in Pittsburgh has significantly reduced the number of patients who develop deadly drug-resistant infections, long a problem in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — At a veterans’ hospital here, nurses swab the nasal passages of every arriving patient to test them for drug-resistant bacteria. Those found positive are housed in isolation rooms behind red painted lines that warn workers not to approach without wearing gowns and gloves.

articles.headline: Global Markets Tumble as Credit Worries Deepen
articles.snippet: The Dow industrials lost more than 300 points Thursday, following similar drops in Europe.  The Nikkei 225 in Japan sank 2.4 percent in trading today.
articles.abstract: The Dow industrials lost more than 300 points Thursday, following similar drops in Europe.  The Nikkei 225 in Japan sank 2.4 percent in trading today.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stock prices tumbled on Wall Street and across much of the rest of the world yesterday. They were driven sharply lower by worries over slowing economic growth in the United States and worsening borrowing conditions that could make everything from huge corporate buyouts to buying a new home more difficult.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: In This Mess, Finger Pointing Is in Style
articles.snippet: Who should take the blame for the chaos in the subprime mortgage industry?
articles.abstract: Who should take the blame for the chaos in the subprime mortgage industry?
articles.lead_paragraph: Who’s to blame for the subprime mortgage mess?

articles.headline: BMW’s Shrine to Horsepower
articles.snippet: BMW is opening a lavish, cathedral-like showroom in Munich to showcase its history and to deliver vehicles, bathed in a spotlight and rotating on a turntable, to their new owners.
articles.abstract: BMW is opening a lavish, cathedral-like showroom in Munich to showcase its history and to deliver vehicles, bathed in a spotlight and rotating on a turntable, to their new owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUNICH, July 20 — Strolling through BMW Welt, with its cyclone-shaped entrance and billowing, cloudlike facade, it is easy to forget why the carmaker built this more than $250 million palace: to hand over cars to customers.

articles.headline: Goldman Bets Hedge Money of Its Own
articles.snippet: Raanan A. Agus, head of Goldman’s equity proprietary trading desk, is starting a hedge fund, but with a twist. His fund will be inside Goldman Sachs itself.
articles.abstract: Raanan A. Agus, head of Goldman’s equity proprietary trading desk, is starting a hedge fund, but with a twist. His fund will be inside Goldman Sachs itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: The equity proprietary trading desk at Goldman Sachs, where traders make bets on stocks with the bank’s own capital, is the American Idol of the trading world.

articles.headline: With Tools on Web, Amateurs Reshape Mapmaking
articles.snippet: New tools are allowing people with minimal skills to do what only professional mapmakers were able to do before.
articles.abstract: New tools are allowing people with minimal skills to do what only professional mapmakers were able to do before.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26  — On the Web, anyone can be a mapmaker.
